data.title: The Eurovision Stars We Lost in 2016
data.meta_description: From past winners to names that few remember now we look and remember those who passed during 2016.
data.text:
It’s the final day of 2015 and as we look forward to a new year of opportunity we also look back at the Eurovision Song Contest stars that we lost during this past year. From past winners to names that few remember now we look and remember those who passed during 2016.

64 Members of the Alexandrov Ensemble Choir – Interval act at Eurovision 2009

The Alexandrov Ensemble Choir will be remembered by Eurovision fans for performing at the Eurovision Song Contest 2009 in Moscow, Russia. The choir performed as the interval act for the first semi final of the contest alongside t.A.T.u. Also performing alongside them at the first semi final were the Dance Ensemble Moscow Military Music School and the Gypsy Theatre Roman.

Corry Brokken – Winner of the Eurovision Song Contest 1957

Brokken was born on 3rd December 1932 in Breda, Netherlands. During the 1950s she became an entertainer and a singer, performing with the Sleeswijk Revue alongside Snip en Snap. She first participated in the contest in its inauguration in 1956 performing the song “Voorgoed Voorbij” (Over Forever) which was composed by Jelle de Vries. In 1957 she went one step further winning the contest in Frankfurt, Germany with the song “Net als toen” (Just Like Then), written by Willy van Hemert with 31 points. In 1958 she participated once again on home soil in Hilversum, this time with the song “Heel de wereld” (The whole world) which didn’t fare as well as her previous attempt, placing her last with one point alongside Luxembourg.

Denis Čabrić – Represented Bosnia & Herzegovina at the Eurovision Song Contest 2009

Denis Čabrić was born in Sarajevo in 1967 had been a member of Regina since they were first formed in 1989. Denis was the bassist for the band and was also known as a director of documentaries and children’s TV. In 2009 Regina gained fame outside of the Balkans when they represented Bosnia & Herzegovina at the Eurovision Song Contest. The band was internally selected by BHRT to represent the country in Moscow with the song “Bistra Voda”. In the final they finished in 9th place with 106 points, the song received Marcel Bezençon Composer award for best song in the competition.

Esma Redžepova – Represented Macedonia at the Eurovision Song Contest 2013

Esma Redžepova who represented Macedonia in Eurovision 2013 with the song “Pred da se razdeni” died at age 73 in the Macedonian capital, Skopje. She was known as a legendary romani queen in the Balkan region. Esma had a worldwide reputation with 50 year-experience. She performed in 30 countries more than 12.000 times. She recorded about 1.000 songs that she wrote herself. The veteran singer represented Macedonia in the Eurovision Song Contest 2013 taking place in Malmö, Sweden as a duo with Vlatko Lozanoski with the song “Pred da se razdeni” and they came 16th gaining 28 points in the semi final.

Jānis Vaišļa – Represented Latvia at the Eurovision Song Contest 2008

Mr Vaišļa had been part of the entertainment scene in Latvia since the 1990s and since 2011 had worked for with the youth association on the creation of a television station. He represented Latvia at the 2008 Eurovision Song Contest as part of the group Pirates of the Sea, they finished 12th in the final with the song “Wolves of the Sea”.

Juraj Černý – Represented Slovakia at the Eurovision Song Contest 1994:

Juraj Černý was a founding member of Tublatanka who were internally selected to represent Slovakia at their debut in the 1994 Eurovision Song Contest in Dublin, Ireland. Tublatanka performed “Nekonečná pieseň” finishing the night in 19th place with 25 points. Juray died at the age of 54.

Kevin Finn – Represented the United Kingdom at the Eurovision Song Contest 1980

The singer rose to fame in the UK as a member of the band The New Seekers, the group scored a number of hits in the UK and abroad. In 1980 Kevin Finn also known as Danny Finn went on to represent the United Kingdom at the Eurovision Song Contest as part of the group Prima Donna. Their song “Love Enough for Two” came 3rd in The Hague, but in the UK it only reached number 48 in the charts.

Lasse Mårtenson – Represented Finland at the Eurovision Song Contest 1964

Lasse represented Finland at the 1964 Eurovision Song Contest in Copenhagen with the song “Laiskotellen”, he finished 7th on the night scoring 9 points. The performance remains one of the best results that Finland has had in the contest. He passed away on the night of the final of the Eurovision Song Contest 2016.

Lola Novaković – Yugoslavia’s entrant in the Eurovision Song Contest 1962

Lola was just the second singer to represent Yugoslavia at the Eurovision Song Contest, she performed “Ne pali svetlo u sumrak” (Don’t turn the lights on at twilight) in Luxembourg and finished in 4th place, it was the countries best result in the contest until 1983. Lola went on to become one of the most well-loved artists in Yugoslavia and performed across the world.

Päivi Paunu – Represented Finland at the Eurovision Song Contest 1972

Päivi Paunu passed away earlier this December at the age of 70. She started off as a folk singer in the 1960s before going on to duet with well-known Finnish performers. In 1972 she was selected to represent Finland at the Eurovision Song Contest with the song “Muistathan”, she finished 12th in Edinburgh scoring a total of 75 points.

Pierre Tchernia – Commentated for France at the Eurovision Song Contest

Mr Tchernia commentated for France at the Eurovision Song Contest a total of 14 times between 1958 and 1974, making him the most prolific commentator France has ever had. Fans of the star of television and cinema, will likely remember him most fondly for his roles in many of the Asterix films. Pierre made his last television appearance in 2008.

Riki Sora – Represented Finland at the Eurovision Song Contest 1980

Riki Sorsa passed away the age of 55, the singers career began in 1974 as the lead singer in the band The Zoo. In 1980 he represented Finland at the Eurovision Song Contest with the song “Reggae OK”, the song was in praise of Reggae music and has gone on to be remembered as one of the more different types of music to be performed on the Eurovision stage.

Roger Cicero – Represented Germany at the Eurovision Song Contest 2008

Roger Cicero was born on July 9, 1970 in Berlin and went on to become one of the biggest names in German jazz music. Roger released eight albums over his career and released 19 singles. In 2007 he was selected to represent Germany at the Eurovision Song Contest with “Frauen regier’n die Welt”, the song went on to reach 7th in the German charts his top charting record of his career. In Helsinki Germany finished the night in 19th place with a total of 49 points.

Sverre Kjelsberg – Represented Norway at the Eurovision Song Contest 1980

Famous for, amongst other things, Norway’s 1980 Eurovision entry ‘Sámiid Ædnan’ (or ‘Lapland’), Sverre Kjelsberg passed away age sixty-nine. Despite finishing in 16th place on the night of the final, Sámiid Ædnan remains a unique and memorable Eurovision hit. Inspired by the autonomy movement among Sami people of Norway, the song referred to political activity including demonstrations held outside the Norwegian building of parliament.

Terry Wogan – Commentator for the United Kingdom at the Eurovision Song Contest

Sir Terry Wogan passed away at the age of 77. The broadcaster who was famous across the United Kingdom, Ireland and around the world for his TV shows and radio show passed away after a short battle with cancer aged 77. Terry Wogan was the voice of the Eurovision Song Contest on radio first in 1971 and then 1974-1977. He took over as the television commentator in 1973 and then 1978 before returning to the commentary booth in 1980 a role he would stay in until 2008. He had a vast impact on generations of viewers in the United Kingdom, through his various TV roles and radio presenting.
